docs.lead_paragraph: More than half of primary care pediatricians have prescribed drugs for sleep problems and nearly three-quarters have recommended over-the-counter medicines, a new study has found. The prescriptions have been issued even though no drugs have been approved for insomnia in children and no guidelines have been generally accepted for prescribing them.

headline.main: Lullabies In a Bottle: Prescribing For Children

docs.abstract: Journal Pediatrics study, surveying 671 pediatricians in 2001, finds that more than half have prescribed drugs for sleep problems and three-quarters have suggested over-counter medicines to aid sleep; lead author Dr Judith A Owens, Brown University Medical School associate professor and pediatric sleep specialist, reports doctors are hesitant to prescribe drugs and are selective about situations in which they do so; researchers agree more study needs to be completed to help guide pediatricians as to appropriate sleep treatments (M)
